Princeton ACM

The official website for the Princeton University student chapter of the Association for Computing Machinery.

Bain & Company

Welcome back to Princeton! The beginning of the year is always a busy and exciting time as you reunite with friends and start new classes. The beginning of your senior year also brings additional challenges as you start to plan for life after Princeton. As you begin this process, we would like to introduce you to Bain & Company.

 

What is Bain?

 

Founded in 1973, Bain & Company is one of the world's top strategy consulting firms helping companies solve some of today’s most complex and challenging business problems.  We make international companies more valuable by combining an analytical approach with results-driven teamwork. Headquartered in Boston, Bain employs 5,500 people in 49 offices in 31 countries around the globe and has been named Consulting Magazine’s “Best Firm to Work For” for eleven consecutive years.

 

What is the Associate Consultant job?

 

The Associate Consultant (AC) position offers Princeton grads a unique opportunity to launch their careers in a fast-paced, challenging, and incredibly rewarding environment. Bain ACs develop advanced business skills helping clients across a broad range of industries solve their most important issues. Simply put, we believe that Bain ACs receive the best practical business experience available, through opportunities to work with major corporate, private equity, and non-profit clients.  We are seeking students of all majors with exceptional records of achievement, strong interpersonal skills, and a passion for what they do.

 

Bain ACs come from a variety of different backgrounds, both personally and academically. For many ACs, their experience over the course of two or three years serves as an outstanding foundation for other opportunities that follow. Many go on to pursue careers in industry, politics and private equity. Others leave Bain to attend top business and law schools or to work at organizations such as the World Economic Forum, the New York City Department of Education, or development NGOs.

 

How do I find out more?

 

Attend our Fall Presentation on Wednesday, September 18th at 8 pm at Prospect House to learn more about Bain and meet our Bainies.

 

Other important dates:

 

  • Social Impact WebEx presentation – September 11th, 1:30 pm-2:30 pm. Please sign up via the Princeton page on www.JoinBain.com – RSVP required.
  • Coffee Chats – September 16th, 11 am-4pm. For more information and to sign up, visit the Princeton page on www.JoinBain.com.
  • BGLAD (Bain’s LGBTQ network) Coffee Chats – September 18th, 6:30 pm – 7:30 pm at Small World Coffee. These will be hosted by Ned Shell, an AC from the New York office. For more information visit the Princeton page on www.JoinBain.com.
  • Resume submission deadline - September 18th 11:59 pm. Please apply via BOTH TigerTracks andwww.JoinBain.com by the application deadline.
  • Career Fair - September 20th at 10:00am, Dillon Gym

 

We also encourage you to explore our website at www.joinbain.com, which includes profiles of Princeton alumni at Bain.

 

We look forward to seeing you this fall!

 

Best,

The Bain Princeton Recruiting Team

September 17, 2013

Ordering Pizza at Code@Night

Every Code@Night we order a solid amount of pizza. 8, 10, 12 pies. Depends on the size of the crowd.

Tonight, we collaboratively programmed a pizza ordering script. We hooked my computer up to the giant monitor in the CITP space in Sherrerd and made this script that would go through the whole pizza ordering process. Selenium allowed us to control the browser programmatically. Having the Selenium driven browser deal with JavaScript was difficult, so we ordered our programmatic pizza through Papa John's mobile site. There were no JavaScript issues there. The process was mostly look up an xpath in chrome, do stuff on that element, repeat. Pretty exciting to watch the script go through and order all our pizza all on its own.

How does programmatic pizza taste compared to your ordinary Code@Night pizza? Couldn't tell you. It's Yom Kippur.

As a side note to those planning future Code@Nights, these events will slow down sooner on Yom Kippur. Generally a good idea to plan around this.

Next steps? Have our script order a completely random pizza. Or take preferences, and order the utility-maximizing combination of pizzas. Or expand to non-Papa-Johns foods. Or... get this... we turn pizza ordering into a one-button process with a Raspberry Pi, which we would of course affectionately name our Raspberry Pizza Pie.

Want to actually implement some of these "next steps"? Dig into the code on Github.

 

September 14, 2013

Battle Road Associates

Our company, Battle Road Associates, LLC., is a small two-man operation started just over a year ago. We're developing a web- and mobile-based application to handle certain kinds of aggregation and processing functions for event data. To start with, we're looking for an intern or two to develop a simple iOS-based front-end to an existing REST API. That project will probably not take the entire summer, and as the project develops we're going to be adding extending the API and adding some additional server-side functionality. Depending on interest and availability, there could be additional part-time or full-time work available after the summer is over as well. We're located in Princeton, but we're looking for someone who can primarily work from home, so location over the summer is not an issue, and we'll also consider someone who already has some summer plans but would be interested in working for us part-time.

Contact Jeff Bagdis '08 <jbagdis@gmail.com> for additional details.

September 12, 2013

Wizoku

Hi!

 

My name is Nick Crosthwaite, and I'm a student at Columbia Business School. This year I started a tutoring company called Wizoku. As founder, I've been working to build a great website and connect with as many students and tutors as possible to build a great learning community. So right now we're in the process of expanding our tutor base and I'm reaching out to you because I thought your club members might be interested in applying.We're in the process of growing our online community and I'm reaching out to you because we are now expanding our reach to Princeton, and I thought your club members might be interested in applying to become one of our Campus Ambassadors.

Wizoku is an online learning community that uses innovative technology to connect students and tutors. Our Campus Ambassadors help us build this community. Effective Ambassadors do this by being active on campus, promoting us on social media, and reaching out to both students and tutors.

Wizoku Ambassadors are paid based on how many tutors and students they can bring to our site. Prospective Ambassadors can click here to apply and learn more about our Ambassador Program.

I'd really appreciate it if you could forward to this email to your club members. We've worked really hard on this site and we're excited about building our community to help as many students as possible. Please also check out our blog to learn more about us and what we do. Thanks so much for your time and please let me know if you have any questions!

Nick Crosthwaite

Co-Founder | Wizoku

718.791.5621 | nick@wizoku.com

September 12, 2013

Present.tv

http://www.present.tv/jobs/

Why join Present?

Present is an early stage startup that allows people to discover, create, and share live video with the world.  We're creating a way for people to see whatever they want to at any time; to feel empowered to see what's happening anywhere without the obstacle of distance.  Present is building the future of media broadcasting, leveling viewers and content creators, and we'd love for you to build with us.

We're a Tigerlabs portfolio company.  Working with us now, you'll participate largely in product development, customer engagement, and business development – every one of us does.  You'll attend speaker series and you'll meet leaders in NYC venture capital, and the startup ecosystem.  The daily grind at this stage is best described as making shit happen – if that's what you're into, you'll fit right in.

Our office is located in Princeton, NJ.

 

Our culture

- Nothing is difficult.

- "Fun": adjective a way to describe a situation in which you have to do something you're not at all familiar with.

- Be adaptable… startup life comes with occasional sharp turns and call-ins.

- See what needs to be done, and make great moves.

- Make mistakes and own them – just don't miss opportunities.  (Recognize, and internalize lessons from those mistakes!)

- Be curious, and question the status quo.

- 'It's impossible' sounds more like 'I have not looked into it.'

 

Benefits & perks

- Play a huge role as an early contributor to Presents' products.

- Play some fierce ping-pong with startups, awesome VCs, and international business leaders.

- Your mentors are leaders in the startup world.

- Contribute business, product, and technology.

 

Other benefits & perks

- Do you like dogs?  Me too!  All week there are dogs around the office

  - Don't worry they aren't in your space if you don't like them ;(

- Ripstick when your not coding.

- Coffee makes you smarter.  Enjoy nearby Small World Coffee.

- ...Yes, there is an Xbox.

If interested in applying, please send your resume and Github to dan@present.tv

September 12, 2013
